questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with hearing issues. During the examination, the audiologist performs the Bing Test and Gelle’s Test to assess the type of hearing loss. What would be indicative of conductive hearing loss in the Bing and Gelle tests?

options.label: A
options.text: Bing: No change; Gelle: No change

questions.correct_answer: A. Bing: No change; Gelle: No change
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Bing Test

Gelle's Test

Purpose

Assess the effect of ear canal occlusion on bone conduction (BC) hearing.

Evaluates the effect of increased air pressure in the ear canal on BC hearing.

Procedure

A tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the ear canal is alternately occluded and unoccluded.

A tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the air pressure in the ear canal is increased using Siegel’s pneumatic speculum.

Normal/SNHL Finding

Sound appears louder when the ear canal is occluded. (Positive)

Hearing decreases with increased air pressure (Positive)

Conductive Loss Finding

No change in sound loudness with ear canal occlusion. (Negative)

No change in hearing with increased air pressure (Negative)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a recent upper respiratory infection presented with ear pain, fullness, hearing difficulties, and dizziness, along with increased pressure during flights and bending over. Which of the following tests is most reliable in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Tympanometry/Inflation-deflation test

(Option B)
  • Principle: When a sound strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected.
  • Normal: The ability of the tube to equilibrate positive and negative pressures to the ambient pressure.

Pneumatic otoscopy

Normal tympanic membrane (tested by otoscope or Siegle’s speculum): Mobile, shiny, pearly grey, has a concave lateral surface (umbo) and a bright light cone in the anteroinferior quadrant.

Nasopharyngoscopy

A flexible nasopharyngoscope can examine the pharyngeal end of the eustachian tube.

Eustachian tube catheterisation

A bent Eustachian tube catheter is passed through the nose to the nasopharynx, where a Politzer's bag is connected to insufflate air. Entry of air into the middle ear is confirmed using an auscultation tube.

Valsalva (Option A)
  • Principle: Create positive pressure in the nasopharynx to allow air into the Eustachian tube.
  • Pinching the nose and taking a deep breath with a closed mouth helps blow air into the ears, moving the tympanic membrane outward.
  • Contraindication: Pharyngitis and sinusitis

 

Politzer test (Option C)

In children who can't perform the Valsalva test, the olive-shaped tip of a Politzer's bag is used; compressing the bag causes the tympanic membrane to bulge.

Toynbee manoeuvre

(Option D)

Toynbee’s manoeuvre causes a negative pressure in the nasopharynx, causing inward retraction of the tympanic membrane.

Frenzel manoeuvre

Performed by divers to equalise middle ear pressure underwater.

Sonotubometry

Measures Eustachian tube opening by applying sound through a nasal probe and recording changes in the external auditory canal during swallowing.

Eustachian tube ventilatory function (researchgate.net)" data-tags="" height="1846" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/E9C9cWQOYfV5mq5ScXkI1738824277.png" width="4167" />

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is referred to the ENT clinic for difficulty hearing in noisy environments and discomfort from loud sounds, affecting his school performance. Which of the following indicates cochlear pathology?
questions.explanation:
Description

Example

Use

The ear that fails to detect low-intensity sounds begins to perceive higher-intensity sounds at levels as loud as or louder than those heard by a normal ear. As a result, a sound that is tolerable in a normal ear may become uncomfortably loud in the recruiting ear.

Cochlear lesions:

  • Meniere’s disease
  • Presbycusis

Distinguish cochlear pathology from retrocochlear.

 

Normal

Cochlear pathology

Retrocochlear pathology

Speech discrimination

score

90-100%

Below 90%

Very poor

Recruitment

(Option D)

Absent

Present

Absent

SISI score

(Option C)

0-15%

>70%

0-20%

Threshold tone decay

Test

(Option B)

0-15 dB

<25 dB

>25 dB

Stapedial reflex

(Option A)

Present

Present

Absent

Stapedial reflex decay

Normal

Normal

Abnormal

BERA

Normal interval between wave I and V

Normal interval between wave I and V

Wave V delayed or absent

Rollover phenomenon

Absent primarily but seen in old age

Absent

Present

questions.text: A 4-month-old was brought to the audiology clinic by his parents due to decreased responsiveness to environmental sounds, such as his name and household noises. Audiology tests were recommended. Which statement about the test shown in the image is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Emissions are generated by inner hair cells

options.label: B
options.text: Spontaneous emissions are present in all individuals

options.label: C
options.text: Evaluates hearing in those with cognitive impairments

questions.correct_answer: C. Evaluates hearing in those with cognitive impairments

questions.text: An infant was brought in due to concerns from her parents about her poor response to loud sounds and reduced reaction to environmental noises compared to her peers. The BERA test shows issues with wave V within the first 10 milliseconds. What site of pathology might this indicate?
questions.explanation:
Wave I

Distal part of CN VIII

Wave II

Proximal part of CN VIII near the brainstem

Wave III

Cochlear nucleus (Option A)

Wave IV

Superior olivary complex (Option B)

Wave V

Lateral lemniscus (Option C)

Wave VI and VII

Inferior Colliculus (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about Electrocochleography(ECochG)?

options.label: A
options.text: Measures the electrical potentials generated in the cochlea and 8th cranial nerve

options.label: B
options.text: A normal SP/AP ratio is greater than 0.3 or 30%

options.label: C
options.text: Can differentiate cochlear pathology from 8th nerve lesions

options.label: D
options.text: Investigation of choice for Meniere's disease

questions.correct_answer: B. A normal SP/AP ratio is greater than 0.3 or 30%

questions.text: A 5-year-old child undergoes acoustic reflex testing during an evaluation for suspected hearing loss. The results indicate the absence of stapedial reflexes at elevated sound levels. Which of the following is the most likely interpretation of this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Normal hearing with no middle ear pathology

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of chronic otitis media presents with progressive hearing loss. Impedance audiometry is performed. Which of the following findings would be pointing towards an underlying middle ear pathology?

options.label: C
options.text: A decreased physical volume of the external auditory canal

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of a robust acoustic reflex at normal sound intensities

questions.explanation:
Tympanogram Type

Characteristics

Indication

Type A

Normal peak

Normal middle ear function

Type As

Shallow peak

Ossicular fixation (e.g., otosclerosis)

Type Ad

Deep peak

Ossicular discontinuity or thin tympanic membrane

Type B

Flat, no peak

Middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane

Type C

Peak at negative pressure

Eustachian tube dysfunction, middle ear negative pressure

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with progressive left ear hearing loss. Audiometry reveals a characteristic dip in the bone conduction curve, more pronounced at 2000 Hz. Which of the following best describes this finding?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Otosclerosis

Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL)

Air Conduction

Loss, more pronounced at lower frequencies

-

Bone Conduction and Characteristic pattern

Normal, may show "Carhart's notch" at 2000 Hz (5-15 dB loss)

Typical notch at 4000 Hz in both air and bone conduction (Boiler's notch) (Option B)

Hearing Loss

Mixed

Sensorineural

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient reports difficulty hearing in the Right ear. Pure tone audiometry is done and the result is given in the image below. Given the audiometric findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Air Conduction (AC)

Bone Conduction (BC)

Frequency Range

125 - 8000 Hz

250 - 4000 Hz

Indicates

Overall hearing sensitivity

Cochlear function

Normal Ear
  • Both AC and BC thresholds are within the normal range (Within 20db in all frequencies)
  • No significant A-B gap

Conductive Hearing Loss
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated (poorer hearing) compared to normal.
  • BC Thresholds: Within normal limits.
  • A-B Gap (>20db): Significant

Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL)

(Option B)
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated to the same degree as AC.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal or absent

Presbycusis

(Option C)
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated, particularly in high frequencies.
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated with greater loss in higher frequencies.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal
  • Downsloping

Meniere’s Disease

(Option D)
  • Upsloping
  • A-B Gap: Typically minimal

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient is being evaluated for hearing loss using various tuning fork tests. What are the expected findings for a patient with sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)?

options.label: A
options.text: Rinne: Positive; Weber: Affected ear; Bing: louder

options.label: B
options.text: Rinne: Positive ; Weber: Better ear ; Schwabach: Shorter

options.label: C
options.text: Rinne: Negative; Schwabach: Longer; Gelle’s: No change.

options.label: D
options.text: ABC: Same; Weber: Unaffected ear; Bing: No change with occlusion.

questions.correct_answer: B. Rinne: Positive ; Weber: Better ear ; Schwabach: Shorter
questions.explanation:
Test

Conductive Hearing Loss

Sensorineural Hearing Loss

Rinne Test

BC > AC (negative)

AC > BC (positive)

Weber Test

Lateralises to the affected ear

Lateralises to the unaffected ear

ABC Test

Same duration as the examiner

Shorter duration than the examiner

Schwabach Test

Longer duration than the examiner

Shorter duration than the examiner

Bing Test

No change with occlusion (negative)

Louder with occlusion (positive)

Gelle’s Test

No change with pressure (negative)

Decreased hearing with increased pressure (positive)

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of structures involved in the transmission of sound from the external environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Pinna → Tympanic membrane → Ossicles → Basilar membrane → Organ of Corti → Auditory nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Tympanic membrane → Pinna → Ossicles → Cochlea → Auditory nerve → Organ of Corti

options.label: C
options.text: Ossicles → Pinna → Tympanic membrane → Organ of Corti → Cochlea → Basilar membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Pinna → Cochlea → Ossicles → Tympanic membrane → Auditory nerve → Basilar membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. Pinna → Tympanic membrane → Ossicles → Basilar membrane → Organ of Corti → Auditory nerve

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) undergoes hearing tests. The examiner performs the Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Test and the Schwabach Test. What are the expected findings of the duration of both tests?

options.label: D
options.text: ABC - Shorter, Schwabach - Same as Examiner

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with hearing loss. On examination, the Weber test indicates that the vibrations are lateralised to the left ear. Given the Weber test findings, which of the following conditions could explain these findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear

options.label: B
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

options.label: C
options.text: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear

options.label: D
options.text: Normal hearing in the left ear

questions.correct_answer: A. Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
questions.explanation:
Type of Hearing Loss

Result

Reason

Conductive Hearing Loss (CHL)

Sound lateralises to the affected ear

In CHL, sound conducted through bone is perceived louder in the ear with impaired air conduction due to decreased ambient noise.

Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL)

Sound lateralises to the unaffected (better) ear

In SNHL, the sound is perceived to be louder in the ear with better cochlear function, as the affected ear struggles with both air-conducted and bone-conducted sounds.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with hearing difficulties. During the Rinne test, bone conduction (BC) is significantly better than air conduction (AC) in the right ear. The Weber test shows lateralisation to the right ear. What is the most likely cause of these findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

options.label: B
options.text: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear

options.label: C
options.text: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear

options.label: D
options.text: Mixed hearing loss in the right ear

questions.correct_answer: B. Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
questions.explanation:
Test

Conductive Loss

Sensorineural Loss

Normal Hearing

How to Perform

Rinne

Negative (BC > AC)

Positive (AC > BC)

Positive (AC > BC)

Place the vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid bone (BC). When sound is no longer heard, move it near the ear canal (AC).

Weber

Lateralises to worse ear

Lateralises to better ear

Heard equally

Place the vibrating tuning fork on the midline of the forehead or the top of the head.

Absolute Bone Conduction

(ABC)

Hears as long as the examiner

Hears for a shorter duration

Hears as long as the examiner

Both the patient's and examiner’s ear canals are occluded. Place the vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid bone.

Schwabach

Lengthened

Reduced

Normal

Place the vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid bone. Compare the duration the patient hears the sound with the examiner’s hearing duration.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with suspected conductive hearing loss undergoes a Rinne test using different tuning forks. The test reveals a better perception of sound through bone conduction compared to air conduction. Which tuning fork frequency is most likely used in this test?
questions.explanation:
Tuning Fork Test Result

Predicted Air-Bone Gap (dB)

Rinne test equal/negative for 256 Hz, positive for 512 Hz

20-30 dB

Rinne test negative for 256 Hz and 512 Hz, positive for 1024 Hz

30-45 dB

Rinne test negative for 256 Hz, 512 Hz, and 1024 Hz

45-60 dB

questions.text: The image given below of the auditory pathway, depicts auditory signals travelling from the cochlea to the primary auditory cortex and passes through the following structures in sequences A, B, C, and D. Which sequence correctly identifies the order of these structures?

options.label: A
options.text: A - Cochlear Nucleus; B - Superior Olivary Complex; C - Inferior Colliculus; D - Medial Geniculate Nucleus

options.label: B
options.text: A - Medial Geniculate Nucleus; B - Cochlear Nucleus; C - Inferior Colliculus; D - Superior Olivary Complex

options.label: C
options.text: A - Inferior Colliculus; B - Cochlear Nucleus; C - Medial Geniculate Nucleus; D - Superior Olivary Complex

options.label: D
options.text: A - Superior Olivary Complex; B - Medial Geniculate Nucleus; C - Cochlear Nucleus; D - Inferior Colliculus

questions.correct_answer: A. A - Cochlear Nucleus; B - Superior Olivary Complex; C - Inferior Colliculus; D - Medial Geniculate Nucleus

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with difficulty localising sounds and a reduced ability to discern speech in noisy environments. He reports no significant hearing loss. Imaging studies reveal normal cochlear and auditory nerve structures, but a lesion is detected in the brainstem. Which structure in the auditory pathway is most likely affected?
Which of the following best describes the role of the phase difference between the oval and round windows in sound transmission?

options.label: A
options.text: It amplifies sound waves by 10 dB

options.label: B
options.text: It prevents the cancellation of sound waves, allowing perilymph movement

options.label: C
options.text: It ensures simultaneous vibration of the oval and round windows

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases sound transmission efficiency, reducing hearing sensitivity by 4 dB

questions.correct_answer: B. It prevents the cancellation of sound waves, allowing perilymph movement

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive hearing loss in his right ear. Audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss, and an MRI shows no abnormalities in the cochlear nerve. A defect in converting mechanical sound vibrations into electrical signals is suspected. Which of the following structures is most likely affected?

What is the total amplification of sound in the auditory system due to impedance matching, considering both the lever action of the ossicles and the area ratio between the tympanic membrane and the oval window?

options.label: A
options.text: 1.3 times from lever action × 17 times from area ratio = 22.1 times

options.label: B
options.text: 1.3 times from lever action × 20 times from area ratio = 26 times

options.label: C
options.text: 1.5 times from lever action × 22 times from area ratio = 33 times

options.label: D
options.text: 1.3 times from lever action × 14 times from area ratio = 18.2 times

questions.correct_answer: D. 1.3 times from lever action × 14 times from area ratio = 18.2 times
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Value

Effective vibratory area of TM

45 mm²

Footplate area

3.2 mm²

Areal ratio

14:1

Lever ratio (ossicles)

1.3:1

Total transformer ratio

18.2:1 (approximately 18:1)

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most important in the impedance-matching mechanism of the auditory system, facilitating the transfer of sound from the air-filled middle ear to the fluid-filled cochlea?

options.label: A
options.text: Acoustic Reflex of the Middle Ear Muscles

options.label: B
options.text: Area ratio between the tympanic membrane and the oval window

options.label: C
options.text: Lever action of the malleus and stapes

questions.correct_answer: B. Area ratio between the tympanic membrane and the oval window
questions.explanation:
Mechanism

Description

Function

Lever Action of the Ossicles

(Option C ruled out)

The malleus has a longer handle compared to the incus, forming a lever system.

Amplifies vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the stapes footplate by a factor of 1.3.

Hydraulic Action of the Tympanic Membrane

The tympanic membrane is larger than the stapes footplate, with an area ratio of about 21:1, reduced to 14:1 due to functional area.

Concentrates force at the smaller stapes footplate, significantly increasing sound pressure.

Curved Membrane Effect

The tympanic membrane is slightly conical, causing greater vibrations at the periphery than at the centre.

Increases the force applied to the ossicles, enhancing sound energy transmission.
